thread.title: IAG gives up five Gatwick slots to gain EU green light for Aer Lingus deal
thread.title_full: IAG gives up five Gatwick slots to gain EU green light for Aer Lingus deal

title: IAG gives up five Gatwick slots to gain EU green light for Aer Lingus deal
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Jul 15, 2015, 00:06 BST - UK Markets open in 7 hrs 54 mins IAG gives up five Gatwick slots to gain EU green light for Aer Lingus deal By Reuters | Telegraph – 1 hour 33 minutes ago 0.346 -0.044 
IAG, which owns British Airways, will also enter into agreements with competing airlines which operate long-haul flights out of Britain 
IAG's €1.3bn takeover of Irish carrier Aer Lingus (LSE: AERL.L - news ) has been approved by European regulators, after the British Airways owner agreed to make concessions to ease competition worries. 
IAG's plan to buy Aer Lingus and build a new transatlantic hub at Dublin airport won the support last week of Ryanair , which holds a 30pc stake in its rival, after convincing the Irish government to sell its 25pc stake in May . 
Reuters reported on Friday that IAG was set to win approval after improving concessions, including giving up some airport slots in London and agreeing to special agreements with rivals, clearing the last hurdle for a takeover that dragged on for months. 
"These commitments adequately address all competition concerns identified by the Commission," the European Commission said in a statement. 
The Commission said it had concerns that the merged entity would have faced insufficient competition on several routes and that it would have also prevented Aer Lingus from continuing to provide traffic to the long-haul flights of competing airlines. 
It confirmed on Tuesday that IAG had submitted commitments to release five daily slots at Gatwick airport to facilitate the entry of competing airlines on routes from London to Dublin and Belfast. 
IAG, which said it "welcomed" the decision, also made a commitment to enter into agreements with competing airlines which operate long-haul flights out of Britain, the Netherlands and Ireland (Other OTC: IRLD - news ) so that Aer Lingus will continue to provide these airlines with connecting passengers. 
Ireland's transport minister welcomed the decision and said officials would review it in order to confirm that there is no impact on the connectivity commitments the government agreed with IAG to win skeptical MPs over. 
Paschal Donohoe said: "I welcome today’s decision by the Commission to approve the acquisition of Aer Lingus by IAG. This decision will now be reviewed in order to confirm that there is no impact on the connectivity commitments agreed with IAG." 
Adding Aer Lingus to its portfolio of airlines - British Airways, Iberia and Spanish budget carrier Vueling - opens a new avenue of growth for IAG, allowing it to expand capacity on lucrative transatlantic routes by using Dublin Airport.
